Award.AwardTitle: Experimental Nuclear Physics and Fundamental Interactions at Indiana University
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research supported by this award investigates: (1) How the spin of the proton is distributed among its parts. Particles emitted when high-energy beams of spin-aligned protons collide in the STAR detector at Brookhaven National Laboratory's Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider can reveal how much of the proton's spin is carried by its gluons or by different types of quarks and anti-quarks. The group will search for the gluon contribution to the spin of the proton and explore spin differences among antiquarks. They will also measure how polarized quarks turn into mesons and baryons and search for indications that strongly interacting matter breaks mirror symmetry;(2) The properties and interactions of neutrinos. Neutrinos can change from one form to another, but all the evidence doesn't quite fit at low energies. They will study the reasons for the larger-than-expected neutrino interactions they have measured; (3) How strong the weak force really is. They will gain new insights by observing the angular distribution of the particles created when a neutron decays, and by testing whether nature respects mirror symmetry as neutrons get captured in hydrogen; and (4) What are the properties of the early universe. They will sharpen theoretical predictions of the amount of helium left over in the Big Bang by measuring the decay rate of the neutron.

Their research activities educate the next generation of skilled PhD scientists for jobs in research and teaching universities, industry and national labs, and medical and computer technology. They redirected their cyclotrons to form the Midwest Proton Radiotherapy Institute, which has treated more than 1000 cancer patients. They co-organize and lecture at summer schools. They participate in the NSF REU program. They mentor their postdocs to facilitate their future entry into teaching and research institutions and the scientific community. They develop undergraduate laboratories emphasizing nuclear technology, bring undergraduates on field trips and assist with programs that encourage pre-college participation in the Indiana University science curriculum. They engage bright young undergraduates in science through jobs or projects which develop the research skills they will need for success in graduate school. They reach out to the local community through a variety of activities to awaken the interest of students in our local public school system by visiting local high school science classes, acting as judges in local science fairs and for the State Science Olympiad, and presenting physics demonstrations at the Indiana State Fair. They actively recruit female and minority applicants for positions at all levels within the group and the physics department by serving on selection committees for faculty searches and research fellowships for women. They work to make their activities known to the public at large through laboratory tours and Open House presentations, science cafe discussions, radio interviews, and press releases in the local media.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The nuclear physics group at Indiana University has made significant progress in answering important scientific questions involving the strong nuclear force and in searching for possible new interactions in Nature. We concentrated our efforts on experiments that directly address these four key areas of inquiry:
(1) How do the quarks and gluons that make up the proton contribute to its observable properties? We used signals from a large detector we built earlier and installed in a detector at Brookhaven National Lab to gain new information on how the quarks and gluons in the proton are spinning. We also used data from a detector at the KEK laboratory in Japan to learn about how quarks that are violently struck inside the proton collect other particles as they try to escape.
(2) How do neutrinos interact with matter? What is dark matter? We measured the probability for neutrinos to create reactions in carbon nuclei, discovered a 30% higher rate than predicted by theory and confirmed this discovery with independent data. We also sough evidence for possible dark matter particles which can appear in our neutrino detector.
(3) Can we find evidence for an electric dipole moment in a fundamental particle, a result that would require violating some of the most basic symmetries of nature? An electric dipole moment, which comes from a separation of positive and negative electric charge, is forbidden for fundamental particles unless the laws of physics depend on the direction of flow of time. We prepared for future experiments in the neutron.
(4) How can we use the strong nuclear force to unravel the details of much weaker forces? We searched for violations of mirror symmetry at the NIST lab near Washington DC by looking to see if spinning neutrons would corkscrew while moving through liquid helium. We finished an experiment at the Spallation Neutron Source at Oak Ridge lab to search for the weak interaction between the neutron and the proton. We measured the lifetime of the neutron in different types of magnetic traps at Los Alamos and NIST. We measured the protons and electrons in neutron decay at NIST to determine the relative odds that they are emitted in the same or opposite directions. We also used neutrons to look for exotic particles that could make up the dark energy or come from string theory.

In addition to these scientific results, we also in parallel developed new technologies to improve our ability to perform more precise experiments in the future. Examples of these new technologies include better ways to detect neutrinos and high energy neutrons,  more efficient electronics to process the required information,  more precise ways to track electrically-charged particles in head-to-head collisions of high energy protons, and better methods to detect very slowly-moving neutrons and measure their spin direction.

The Indiana nuclear physics group has a long tradition of training outstanding undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdocs who succeed both as scientific researchers and educators and also in professional roles in the private sector.  Over the last two years 10 IU students received their Ph.D. degrees.  Eight are now postdoctoral research associates at universities or national labs and two are employed in finance. Roughly a third of our students have been recipients of either national or university-wide awards or fellowships. Of the three postdocs working in our group during this period, two became assistant professors in universities. More than twenty undergraduate students received their first real scientific research experiences in our group, and some of them have now gone on to further education in various graduate and professional programs. We conducted several forms of scientific outreach to our local community through our annual Physics Department Open House, tours of our research facility on the IU Bloomington campus (The Center for the Exploration of Energy and Matter), participation in exhibits at the local Wonderlab science museum, exhibits at the Indiana State Fair, interviews with our local community radio station, and scientific demonstrations at local grade schools.
